metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the operation of simple DC motors consisting of one coil, containing a number of loops of wire, which is free to rotate about an axis in a uniform magnetic field and including the use of a split ring commutator

motor_components.name: DC Motor Components
motor_components.correct: A simple DC motor consists of a coil (armature) free to rotate in a magnetic field, connected to a DC supply via brushes and a split ring commutator.

slip rings instead of split ring commuta.error: Slip rings are for AC generators, not DC motors.
slip rings instead of split ring commuta.fix: DC motors need a split ring commutator to reverse current direction every half rotation.
slip rings instead of split ring commuta.action: Compare: split ring has a gap and reverses current; slip rings maintain continuous contact.

AC power supply.error: DC motors use direct current, not alternating current.
AC power supply.fix: The 'DC' in DC motor stands for direct current. AC motors have different designs.
AC power supply.action: Remember: DC motors need commutators because DC doesn't naturally reverse.

single wire instead of coil.error: A single wire produces minimal force. Coils multiply the effect.
single wire instead of coil.fix: Using n turns of wire multiplies the force by n. F = nIlB.
single wire instead of coil.action: Each loop adds another force contribution to the torque.

persistent.gap: You're confusing DC motor components with other electrical devices.
persistent.action: Draw and label a complete DC motor diagram including coil, magnets, brushes, and split ring commutator.

magnetic_force_on_wire.name: Magnetic Force on Current-Carrying Wire
magnetic_force_on_wire.correct: The force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is F = nIlB, where n is the number of turns, I is current, l is wire length, and B is magnetic field strength.

F = IlB (missing n).error: This is correct for a single wire, but coils have multiple turns.
F = IlB (missing n).fix: For a coil with n turns, multiply by n: F = nIlB.
F = IlB (missing n).action: Check if the question mentions number of turns or loops.

F = nIB (missing l).error: You forgot the length of wire in the field.
F = nIB (missing l).fix: Force depends on how much wire is in the field. F = nIlB.
F = nIB (missing l).action: Only the wire length perpendicular to B contributes to force.

F = nIlB² (wrong power of B).error: Force is proportional to B, not B².
F = nIlB² (wrong power of B).fix: The formula is linear in all variables: F = nIlB.
F = nIlB² (wrong power of B).action: Double the field strength → double the force, not quadruple.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise the motor force formula.
persistent.action: Practice: F = nIlB. Each letter is a multiplying factor.

force_direction.name: Force Direction (Right-Hand Rule)
force_direction.formula: Right-hand palm rule: fingers = B, thumb = I, palm pushes = F
force_direction.correct: The direction of force on a current-carrying wire is found using the right-hand palm rule: fingers point in field direction, thumb in current direction, palm pushes in force direction.

left-hand rule.error: Left-hand rule is an alternative convention, but VCE uses right-hand palm rule.
left-hand rule.fix: Use right hand: fingers = B, thumb = I, palm = F.
left-hand rule.action: Practise the right-hand palm rule until it's automatic.

fingers along current.error: Fingers should point along the magnetic field, not current.
fingers along current.fix: Thumb = current (I), Fingers = field (B), Palm = force (F).
fingers along current.action: Think: 'I' for 'I use my thumb' → thumb = current.

thumb along magnetic field.error: Thumb should point along current, not field.
thumb along magnetic field.fix: Fingers = B (field), Thumb = I (current), Palm = F (force).
thumb along magnetic field.action: The thumb is for current (I), fingers for field (B).

persistent.gap: You're mixing up the hand rule conventions.
persistent.action: Use ONLY right-hand palm rule: fingers = B, thumb = I, palm pushes = F. Practise 10 examples.

torque_definition.name: Torque (Turning Effect)
torque_definition.correct: Torque is the turning effect of a force, calculated as τ = rF where r is the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force.

τ = F only.error: Torque depends on both force AND lever arm distance.
τ = F only.fix: Torque = force × lever arm. τ = rF.
τ = F only.action: Same force further from pivot → greater torque.

τ = r + F.error: Torque is a product, not a sum.
τ = r + F.fix: Multiply force by distance: τ = rF, not r + F.

τ = F/r.fix: Torque increases with distance: τ = rF, not F/r.
τ = F/r.action: Longer wrench = more torque for same force.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what torque measures.
persistent.action: Torque = how hard something wants to rotate. τ = rF. More distance or more force → more torque.

torque_in_motor.name: Torque in DC Motors
torque_in_motor.correct: Motor torque depends on the magnetic force on the coil sides. Increasing n, I, l, or B increases the force and therefore the torque.

torque only depends on current.error: Current is one factor, but not the only one.
torque only depends on current.fix: Torque depends on n, I, l, and B. All affect the force F = nIlB.
torque only depends on current.action: List all factors: number of turns, current, length, field strength.

torque is constant during rotation.error: Torque varies as the coil rotates.
torque is constant during rotation.fix: Torque is maximum when coil is horizontal, zero when vertical.
torque is constant during rotation.action: When coil is vertical, forces act through the axis → no turning effect.

increasing speed increases torque.error: Speed is a result of torque, not a cause.
increasing speed increases torque.fix: Torque causes acceleration. Increasing n, I, l, or B increases torque.
increasing speed increases torque.action: Don't confuse cause (torque) with effect (rotation speed).

persistent.gap: You're confusing torque factors with rotation speed.
persistent.action: Focus on what creates force: F = nIlB. More force on coil sides → more torque.

torque_variation.name: Torque Variation During Rotation
torque_variation.formula: τ_max when horizontal, τ = 0 when vertical
torque_variation.correct: Torque is maximum when the coil is horizontal (forces at maximum lever arm) and zero when vertical (forces act through the axis of rotation).

torque maximum when vertical.error: Opposite. Torque is zero when vertical.
torque maximum when vertical.fix: When vertical, forces act along the axis—no perpendicular distance from pivot.
torque maximum when vertical.action: Lever arm is zero when coil is vertical. τ = rF = 0 × F = 0.

torque constant throughout.error: Torque varies continuously as the coil rotates.
torque constant throughout.fix: Lever arm changes as coil rotates. Maximum when horizontal, zero when vertical.
torque constant throughout.action: Draw coil at different angles and identify the lever arm at each.

torque zero when horizontal.error: Opposite. Torque is maximum when horizontal.
torque zero when horizontal.fix: Horizontal position has maximum lever arm distance from the axis.
torque zero when horizontal.action: Lever arm = half the coil width when horizontal.

persistent.gap: You're not visualising how lever arm changes during rotation.
persistent.action: Draw the coil at 0°, 45°, and 90°. Mark the lever arm at each position.

commutator_purpose.name: Split Ring Commutator Purpose
commutator_purpose.correct: The split ring commutator reverses the direction of current in the coil every half rotation, ensuring the force direction reverses so the coil continues rotating in the same direction.

maintains constant current direction.error: That's what slip rings do, not split ring commutators.
maintains constant current direction.fix: Split ring commutators REVERSE current every half turn to maintain rotation direction.
maintains constant current direction.action: Split = gap → connection reverses as gap passes brushes.

increases current.fix: Commutators control current DIRECTION, not magnitude.
increases current.action: Current magnitude is set by voltage and resistance.

reverses current every quarter rotation.error: Wrong timing. Reversal occurs every HALF rotation.
reverses current every quarter rotation.fix: The split ring has two halves. Each brush contacts a different half every half turn.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the commutator's switching mechanism.
persistent.action: Draw the commutator at 0°, 90°, 180°, 270°. Track which brush contacts which wire.

commutator_vs_slip_rings.name: Split Ring vs Slip Rings
commutator_vs_slip_rings.formula: Split ring for DC motors, slip rings for AC generators
commutator_vs_slip_rings.correct: Split ring commutators reverse current for continuous DC motor rotation. Slip rings maintain constant connection and are used in AC generators.

slip rings for DC motors.error: With slip rings, a DC motor would oscillate, not rotate continuously.
slip rings for DC motors.fix: DC motors need current reversal every half turn → split ring commutator.
slip rings for DC motors.action: Without current reversal, forces would reverse the coil's motion after half a turn.

split ring for AC output.error: Split ring commutators produce DC output, not AC.
split ring for AC output.fix: Split ring converts AC in coil to DC at output. Slip rings maintain AC.
split ring for AC output.action: DC generators use split rings. AC alternators use slip rings.

both do the same thing.fix: Split ring reverses connections; slip rings maintain continuous connection.
both do the same thing.action: Split = gap that reverses; slip = continuous ring that doesn't reverse.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the two types of commutators.
persistent.action: Make a comparison table: split ring (DC, reverses) vs slip rings (AC, continuous).

dead_spot.name: Vertical Position (Dead Spot)
dead_spot.formula: No current, no torque at vertical position
dead_spot.correct: When the coil reaches the vertical position, the brushes contact the gap in the split ring, no current flows, and torque is zero. The motor continues due to momentum.

motor stops at vertical.error: The motor's momentum carries it through the dead spot.
motor stops at vertical.fix: Angular momentum keeps the coil rotating even when torque is momentarily zero.
motor stops at vertical.action: Like a bicycle freewheeling—momentum carries through the dead spot.

maximum current at vertical.error: Opposite. There's no current at the vertical position.
maximum current at vertical.fix: Brushes contact the gap when vertical. No circuit = no current.
maximum current at vertical.action: The gap in the split ring breaks the circuit momentarily.

maximum torque at vertical.error: Torque is zero at vertical—forces act through the axis.
maximum torque at vertical.fix: Even if there were current, the lever arm would be zero at vertical.
maximum torque at vertical.action: Two reasons for zero torque: no current AND zero lever arm.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the vertical position behaviour.
persistent.action: At vertical: circuit broken (gap), lever arm = 0, but momentum continues rotation.

motor_energy_conversion.name: Energy Conversion in Motors
motor_energy_conversion.correct: A DC motor converts electrical potential energy into kinetic energy (rotational motion) through the magnetic force on current-carrying wires.

kinetic to electrical.error: That's a generator, not a motor.
kinetic to electrical.fix: Motor: electrical → kinetic. Generator: kinetic → electrical.
kinetic to electrical.action: Motor CONSUMES electricity to produce motion.

thermal to kinetic.error: DC motors don't use heat as input.
thermal to kinetic.fix: Input is electrical energy. Some is lost as heat, but heat isn't the input.
thermal to kinetic.action: Motors run on electricity, not heat (that would be a heat engine).

magnetic to electrical.error: The magnetic field provides force, but doesn't supply energy.
magnetic to electrical.fix: Energy comes from the electrical supply. Field just redirects forces.
magnetic to electrical.action: Magnetic field is permanent; electrical supply provides the energy.

persistent.gap: You're confusing motors with generators or other devices.
persistent.action: Motor = electrical IN, motion OUT. Generator = motion IN, electrical OUT.

rotation_direction.name: Determining Rotation Direction
rotation_direction.formula: Use right-hand rule on both sides, find turning effect
rotation_direction.correct: Apply the right-hand palm rule to each side of the coil to find force directions. The pair of forces creates a torque that determines rotation direction.

only check one side.error: Both sides contribute to the turning effect.
only check one side.fix: Check force on both vertical sides. They should form a force pair creating rotation.
only check one side.action: One side up, one side down = rotation. Both same direction = no rotation.

current direction determines rotation di.error: Current direction alone isn't enough—you also need field direction.
current direction determines rotation di.fix: Rotation depends on both current AND field direction via the right-hand rule.
current direction determines rotation di.action: Apply right-hand rule: need both I and B to find F.

field direction determines rotation dire.error: Field direction alone isn't enough—you also need current direction.
field direction determines rotation dire.fix: Force direction depends on both field AND current direction.
field direction determines rotation dire.action: Right-hand rule combines I and B to give F.

persistent.gap: You're not systematically applying the right-hand rule to both sides.
persistent.action: For each problem: apply rule to left side, apply rule to right side, combine for rotation direction.
